title: More protests as Poland puts into effect strict new anti-abortion laws - ABC News
meta_title: More protests as Poland puts into effect strict new anti-abortion laws - ABC News
description: Poland's Government says it is ready to implement strict new abortion laws that will ban terminations of pregnancies with foetal defects, sparking fresh protests by those who say the law will harm women.

Sokolowski)abc.net.au/news/poland-puts-into-effect-new-restrictions-on-abortion/13098034Link copiedShareShare articlePoland's Government says it is ready to implement strict new abortion laws that will ban terminations of pregnancies with foetal defects, sparking fresh protests by those who say the law will harm women.Key points:Officials said the Government would now focus on assisting parents of disabled childrenThe ruling party denied Opposition criticism that it had influenced a court decision on the banProtesters say the "idiotic" law will harm womenThe October 22 ruling on the ban, handed down by the Constitutional Tribunal, led to some of the biggest protests in the country's history.The nationalist Law and Justice (PiS) Government decided to delay its implementation as a result.However PiS announced on Wednesday local time that it would take the official step to enforce the decision imminently.Under the new rules, terminations will be permitted only in cases of rape and incest, and when the mother's life or health is endangered.Doctors performing illegal abortions in Poland face jail.Small protests took place following the announcement, and abortion rights activists said more would take place on Thursday."This idiotic ruling will not prevent abortions," said Cezary Jasiaski, a 23-year-old student, standing in front of the Constitutional Tribunal building in central Warsaw."But for every woman who will experience pain because of this ruling, or will be forced to give birth to a child with Down's Syndrome, they [court judges] will be to blame."Abortion has emerged as one of the most divisive issues since PiS took power in 2015, promising poorer, older and less educated Poles in one of Europe's most devout Catholic countries a return to a traditional society mixed with generous welfare policies.Last year's protests quickly morphed into an eruption of anger against the Government, particularly among young people, suggesting PiS may face a fresh challenge from new voters in coming years.More women seeking abortions abroad People marched near the front of the Constitutional Tribunal headquarters in Warsaw, Poland.(AP: Czarek Sokolowski)On Wednesday, officials said the Government would now focus on assisting parents of disabled children, although PiS and its centrist predecessors have been accused by critics of not doing enough in that regard."The state can no longer take a life away only because someone is sick, disabled, in poor health," PiS lawmaker Bartlomiej Wroblewski said.The party has denied Opposition criticism that it influenced the tribunal in its decisionIt is one of the judicial bodies PiS overhauled during reforms that the European Union said has politicised the courts system.Why events in Poland matterMany fear Poland is now on the road from liberal democracy to authoritarianism, as an increasingly vocal far-right fringe movement grows.Read moreAccess to abortion in Poland has declined even without the legislative curbs as more doctors refuse to perform them on religious grounds and many women seek abortions abroad.In a justification published on Wednesday, the tribunal left open the possibility of Parliament regulating some circumstances covered by the law.Marek Suski, a PiS lawmaker, said the party would consider introducing new rules that could allow the most extreme foetal deformities to be excluded.But political commentators say consensus between PiS and its arch-conservative governing allies would be difficult to achieve."In cases when the foetus doesn't have a skull or has no chance to live outside the womb, there should be a choice. We will work on this," Mr Suski told public radio.Opinion surveys have shown some decline in PiS popularity in recent months, but an opinion poll by the Government-affiliated CBOS pollster showed it edging back up to 35 per cent this month, from 30 per cent in October.PiS and its two small parliamentary allies won re-election in 2019 with a 44 per cent share of the vote.Loading YouTube contentReutersPosted 28 Jan 202128 Jan 2021Thu 28 Jan 2021 at 1:29am, updated 28 Jan 202128 Jan 2021Thu 28 Jan 2021 at 1:44amShareCopy linkFacebookX (formerly Twitter)Related StoriesTens of thousands take to streets of Warsaw in continuing protests against new anti-abortion lawsPoland's top court created a near-total ban on abortions.
